text: Artificial Intelligence (AI) will permanently change the economic value chain across industries and sizes as a central disruptive technological innovation.
label: auxiliary

text: The specialists and managers required for this transformation process must be trained early.
label: auxiliary

text: The joint project KI B³ (Künstliche Intelligenz in die Berufliche Bildung bringen) addresses the previously missing qualification opportunities for data analysis and machine learning skills in vocational and further training.
label: auxiliary

text: It is initially based on regional legal provisions that will be rolled out across Baden-Württemberg and combined to create national statutory ordinances.
label: auxiliary

text: The newly formed innovation cluster, which is composed of three Baden-Württemberg IHKs (Karlsruhe, Region Stuttgart, and Reutlingen) and the Technical University of Munich, Stuttgart, and Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich (LMU), has been developing a modular format that provides a cross-industry additional qualification to connect trainees with advanced training qualifications.
label: auxiliary

text: This is related to a deeper reflection on the creditability within vocational training and the exchange with academic education in the sense of a "currency." Since much of the AI content is currently being taught primarily in academic education, the specific skills should get into vocational training via adapted or revised digital modules.
label: auxiliary

text: This software requires specification details regarding the software developed to support teaching content and the heterogeneous group of learners.
label: auxiliary

text: The project is supported by an extensive network that includes three Baden-Württemberg IHKs and various companies, unions, state ministries, a vocational school, the DIHK, and the DIHK Bildungs-GmbH, employment agencies, and scientific experts.
label: auxiliary

text: This learning software is built upon the Moodle platform, enhanced with custom features to address diverse student needs by ensuring equal access to personalized educational content and adaptive support.
label: auxiliary

text: Integrating an AI Chatbot as a digital tutor, guiding students with tailored feedback, adaptive assistance, and individualized tasks.
label: auxiliary

text: Additionally, it integrates a Jupyter programming environment directly into Moodle, enhancing students' programming skills.
label: auxiliary

text: Designed for hybrid learning environments, it combines Moodle's foundational structure with effective didactic strategies and added collaborative features such as discussion forums, badges, notifications, and real-time communication.
label: auxiliary

text: Integrated functionalities like Python programming and machine learning further allow students to engage in hands-on learning within the platform.
label: auxiliary

text: This comprehensive design supports both students and educators in managing, tracking, and engaging effectively with the learning process.
label: auxiliary

text: This document is created based on the IEEE template [1] for System Requirement Specification Documents.
label: auxiliary

text: Furthermore, the requirements language criteria are based on ISO 29148 [2], i.e., this is a harmonized standard of IEEE 830 [3].
label: auxiliary

text: Intended Audience and Suggestions
label: auxiliary

text: The intended audience is cross-industry, to which the digital modules and adaptive learning software shall be deployed in three phases:
label: auxiliary

text: In Baden-Württemberg: trials in three Industrie- und Handelskammer (IHK) model regions (IHK districts Karlsruhe, Reutlingen, Region Stuttgart), then roll out the modules and software to the remaining 9 IHK districts.
label: auxiliary

text: And nationwide perspective roll-out, i.e., creating a national ordinance based on tried and tested regional regulations.
label: auxiliary

text: This adaptive learning software is developed as part of a larger educational project for IHK, leveraging the Moodle platform with custom enhancements to serve as a comprehensive "learning assistant." It uses AI-driven methods to assess and promote each student's knowledge level and skills.
label: auxiliary

text: By integrating an AI chatbot, Jupyter programming environment, and additional collaborative tools, this platform offers adaptive assistance and feedback tailored to individual learning needs.
label: auxiliary

text: This approach ensures each student receives targeted guidance and resources to foster growth within a supportive hybrid learning environment.
label: auxiliary

text: Selection of the Base Learning Platform
label: auxiliary

text: An analysis of several existing learning platforms was conducted, into which the aimed adaptive learning software could be integrated to meet the requirements (see Section 7).
label: auxiliary

text: The criteria used to select Moodle as the base platform for designing and developing the adaptive learning software.
label: auxiliary

text: A literature review was conducted to find the best learning platforms for further customization of the KIB3’s needs according to the elicited software requirements.
label: auxiliary

text: Among all three e-learning platforms that were narrowed down for further analysis are Moodle, ILIAS, and Chamilo.
label: auxiliary

text: Closed-source e-learning platforms were excluded since one of the goals of the KIB3 project is to follow the open-source paradigm.
label: auxiliary

text: The three selected e-learning platforms were compared based on their features and capabilities, technical aspects, and the coverage of the KIB3 project's functional and non-functional requirements.
label: auxiliary

text: Furthermore, available studies in the literature and deployment experience reports were also considered during the selection process.
label: auxiliary

text: Since the beginning of COVID-19, a bulk of new research has been published, specifically in rating virtual learning platforms to replace or be the nearest replacement for face-to-face classes.
label: auxiliary

text: Most of such publications recommend the use of Moodle.
label: auxiliary

text: The following lists a subset of the reasons why they recommend using Moodle.
label: auxiliary

text: - It is an open-source project based on the GNU license [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 14].
label: auxiliary

text: - It is a Content Management System and Virtual Learning Environment that provides its users with learner tools such as communication, productivity, and student involvement.
label: auxiliary

text: Moreover, it provides support tools such as administration, course management, and content development [2, 6, 10, 11, 14].
label: auxiliary

text: - Moodle is easy to set up and can run on almost all servers that support PHP.
label: auxiliary

text: Moreover, it is easy to upgrade from one version to another [7, 4, 8, 10, 12, 13].
label: auxiliary

text: - The key to Moodle's success in academia is its development, which considers both pedagogy and technology by providing a solid grounding in social constructionist pedagogy and good education [5, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, 16, 17].
label: auxiliary

text: - It has many valuable features that can promote it as an alternative to face-to-face classes, such as easy installation, customization of options and settings, good support, and proper educational tools.
label: auxiliary

text: Moreover, it has excellent documentation and strong support for security and administration [9, 10, 12, 14, 15, 16].
label: auxiliary

text: Additionally, other advantages were not discussed in previous studies.
label: auxiliary

text: Moodle is a plugin-based platform and provides a plugin marketplace (repository) with hundreds of already developed plugins, such as plugins for adding interactivity, communication tools, computer programming environments, and administration tools.
label: auxiliary

text: Moreover, Moodle has object-oriented and modular source-code configurations [5], making it easier to maintain and develop on top of it, which is one of the essential issues in the e-learning platforms ILIAS and Chamilio.
label: auxiliary

text: Finally, Moodle has a massive developer community with continuous releases of newer versions, which guarantees long-term support of the project and security assurance due to security updates in newer releases.
label: auxiliary

text: In addition to the aforementioned publications that describe the qualities of Moodle, it is also crucial to consider some statistics about Moodle.
label: auxiliary

text: Moodle currently has (as of 05.08.2021) about 187K registered sites with 277M users and over 1.5B enrollments running in 246 countries [5].
label: auxiliary

text: To this date, Germany ranks fourth top Moodle user globally with 10135 registered sites [5].
label: auxiliary

text: Additionally, the vocational training school of Balingen has already been using Moodle.
label: auxiliary

text: This training school is an important KIB3 stakeholder, which works closely with this project to support us in achieving the project's goals by providing us with information about the vocational training school’s needs.
label: auxiliary

text: In summary, we selected the learning platform Moodle as the base platform for KIB3's adaptive learning software based on (i) the aforementioned reasons derived from recent studies, (ii) Moodle’s functionalities that cover most of the basic requirements for this project.
label: auxiliary

text: This section outlines the requirements elicitation process, led by the Chair of Software Engineering at the Technical University of Munich, detailing the collaborative steps taken to gather and refine project requirements.
label: auxiliary

text: It concludes with the final list of requirements, organized into functional and non-functional categories, forming the foundation for the software’s development.
label: auxiliary

text: The requirements elicitation process for this project, led by the Chair of Software Engineering at the Technical University of Munich, began during the COVID-19 pandemic when physical meetings were not possible.
label: auxiliary

text: Consequently, all elicitation activities were conducted through online meetings with stakeholders.
label: auxiliary

text: This remote collaboration included representatives from a range of organizations, such as IHK Reutlingen (IHK RT), IHK Karlsruhe (IHK KA), IHK Region Stuttgart (IHK RS), the Institute for Natural Language Processing at the University of Stuttgart, and Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich (LMU), as well as several school teachers, ensuring a comprehensive blend of expertise.
label: auxiliary

text: The process began with a literature review conducted by software engineers at the Chair of Software Engineering, identifying general categories of functionalities, such as basic functions and chatbot tutoring, based on existing AI-supported learning platforms.
label: auxiliary

text: Before moving into breakout sessions, stakeholders were invited to suggest any additional categories they felt should be included.
label: auxiliary

text: Participants were then divided into breakout sessions according to their expertise, where they discussed and brainstormed ideas using mind maps.
label: auxiliary

text: These mind maps were subsequently consolidated and transformed into requirements compliant with ISO 29148 standards.
label: auxiliary

text: A follow-up validation meeting allowed stakeholders to review the drafted requirements, remove unfeasible ones, and finalize an agreed-upon list.
label: auxiliary

text: This final list was classified into functional and non-functional categories, establishing a structured foundation for the software's development.
label: auxiliary

text: Each plug-in is designed with a specific intended use, ranging from interactive educational tools to background processes that improve system performance and adaptability.
label: auxiliary

text: A detailed description of each plug-in is provided in the following section.
label: auxiliary

text: The development of these plug-ins ensures a robust, flexible platform that meets KIB3’s educational needs through tailored, interactive, and efficient functionality.
label: auxiliary

text: This modular design, combining student-facing and backend plug-ins, allows the platform to support a dynamic and adaptive learning experience effectively.
label: auxiliary

text: The KIB3 Chatbot, Moodle Assistant, is a custom-built chatbot designed to enhance the learning experience within Moodle courses.
label: auxiliary

text: Acting as a digital tutor, the assistant provides real-time support, helping students navigate course content, find resources, and receive assistance on demand.
label: auxiliary

text: Integrated directly into Moodle, the chatbot appears on course pages, offering interactive guidance, answering questions, and assisting students in searching through learning materials using the Book Search plug-in (see Section 9.3) or accessing supplementary tools like the Ice-Cream Game.
label: auxiliary

text: The KIB3 Moodle Assistant adapts to each course’s needs by leveraging AI, making learning more accessible and engaging.
label: auxiliary

text: This assistant provides personalized support for students and streamlines the educational process by automating responses and offering relevant resources.
label: auxiliary

text: The Icecream Game is a Moodle plugin designed to introduce students to the basics of machine learning through an engaging, interactive guessing game.
label: auxiliary

text: In this activity, learners are asked to predict ice cream sales, with each participant selecting from three groups that represent different machine learning strategies.
label: auxiliary

text: The game begins with an introductory video, after which students choose a group.
label: auxiliary

text: This choice is irreversible and stored in the Moodle database and the browser cache.
label: auxiliary

text: Each group receives information about expected sales in varying formats.
label: auxiliary

text: Using the information provided, students make predictions for a specific day, with the option to configure the number of guesses.
label: auxiliary

text: Upon completion, learners receive feedback on their results.
label: auxiliary

text: This activity introduces students to machine learning concepts and fosters critical thinking and data interpretation skills.
label: auxiliary

text: The Book Search plugin is a tool designed to enable text search within Moodle books that contain image-based chapters.
label: auxiliary

text: It provides a convenient search field that allows users to search for specific text within PDF files corresponding to book chapters.
label: auxiliary

text: For the search functionality to work, a PDF file with (almost) the same name as the Moodle book must be present in the course, with each PDF page aligning one-to-one with the book pages.
label: auxiliary

text: Search results appear as clickable links, directing users to the relevant page within the book.
label: auxiliary

text: This plugin can be configured as a block within Moodle, or accessed via a web service for additional flexibility.
label: auxiliary

text: By enabling streamlined navigation through course materials, the Book Search plugin enhances the accessibility of learning resources within Moodle, making it easier for students to find and reference key information.
label: auxiliary

text: The plugin’s interaction flow and usage are further illustrated in Figure 4.
label: auxiliary

text: Figure 4: Book Search architecture and possible interactions
label: auxiliary

text: The Jupyter Moodle Plugin integrates Jupyter Notebooks into Moodle, providing students with a virtual programming environment directly within the platform.
label: auxiliary

text: By connecting to a JupyterHub server, this plugin authenticates Moodle users, allowing them seamless access to Jupyter notebooks from within Moodle.
label: auxiliary

text: The plugin also supports automated grading through Otter-Grader, enabling instructors to assess assignments efficiently and consistently.
label: auxiliary

text: With the Jupyter Moodle Plugin, educators can create programming assignments that students can complete within embedded notebooks, fostering hands-on learning experiences in fields such as Python programming and data science.
label: auxiliary

text: The integration streamlines coding exercises by offering a centralized platform for coding, testing, and grading, all within the familiar Moodle interface.
label: auxiliary

label: auxiliary

text: The Autocomplete Related Activities plugin streamlines activity completion tracking in Moodle courses that provide the same content in multiple formats, such as an interactive book, PDF, or video link.
label: auxiliary

text: When a student completes any of these alternative formats, the plugin automatically marks the other formats in the same section as complete, reducing redundant tasks for learners.
label: auxiliary

text: The plugin uses a configurable regular expression to identify alternative materials within a section, marking all as complete once any one format is completed.
label: auxiliary

text: Additionally, it supports an optional "I know this already" label, allowing students to bypass a section entirely if they feel confident with the material.
label: auxiliary

text: This label is automatically marked complete when any of the alternatives are completed, although marking the label alone does not affect the status of the alternatives.
label: auxiliary

text: This plugin activates only in courses configured by the administrator, enhancing the course experience by allowing flexible learning paths and tracking student progress across various content formats.
label: auxiliary

text: The Genbook plugin enables the generation of Moodle books directly from image files, providing a streamlined way to create book resources within courses.
label: auxiliary

text: Developed specifically to assist content developers in the KIB3 project, Genbook is designed for a specialized use case and may have limited applicability outside this project context.
label: auxiliary

text: Using the plugin, content creators can easily compile a series of images into a Moodle book by selecting a course section, specifying a book title, and uploading images as individual chapters.
label: auxiliary

text: Each chapter is defined by a configuration file that links images to chapter names.
label: auxiliary

text: This tool simplifies the process of creating structured learning materials, making it easier for developers to organize visual content as structured book resources.

text: Alternative Packaging and Delivery with Moodle Docker
label: auxiliary

text: To make the installation and configuration of Moodle with multiple custom plugins and course materials easier, Docker provides a reliable solution for consistent deployments.
label: auxiliary

text: The Moodle Docker plugin offers a one-click setup for deploying Moodle, complete with all necessary plugins and teaching materials tailored specifically for KIB3 courses.
label: auxiliary

text: Currently supporting the “Zusatzqualifikation” module (with DQR5 support coming soon), this Docker-based package automates the installation process, streamlining course deployment for educators and administrators.
label: auxiliary

text: With this setup, Moodle is delivered as a fully configured, ready-to-use environment.
label: auxiliary

text: The plugin enables rapid deployment by packaging everything needed for a complete Moodle instance, including course backups, plugin installations, and necessary configurations.
label: auxiliary

text: By utilizing Docker, users can easily manage server settings, adjust resource allocations, and enable SSL, creating a robust and consistent Moodle environment with minimal effort.
label: auxiliary

text: This tool simplifies course setup, making it an ideal solution for delivering standardized learning environments across KIB3’s educational initiatives.
label: auxiliary

text: The Docker package for Moodle Docker is available for download here: https://github.com/SE-Stuttgart/kib3_moodle_docker
label: auxiliary
